Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary aim of this proposal is to deepen our understanding of several classes of regular cell complexes through the study of their face numbers. Specifically, research on this project will involve the use of algebraic, geometric, topological, and combinatorial methods to attack fundamental enumerative questions involving balanced and flag simplicial complexes, cubical complexes, simplicial manifolds and pseudomanifolds.

Cell complexes provide a convenient way to build various shapes from smaller and simpler blocks, such as from pyramids or cubes. A natural question is: What restrictions on the number of building blocks are imposed by specific shapes? Variations of this question (e.g., What is the minimum number of blocks required?) have practical importance when one wants to represent or store such a structure in a computer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was aimed at attacking several long-standing problems and conjectures in the theory of face numbers of various classes of simplicial complexes. A simplicial complex is constructed from points, segments, triangles, pyramids, and higher-dimensional analogs of pyramids by gluing these objects so that every two of them are either disjoint or intersect along their common face.  Examples of simplicial complexes include polygons, pyramids, and their higher-dimensional generalizations. For instance, a graph is a one-dimensional simplicial complex. Simplicial complexes are among the central objects in the field of geometric combinatorics --- a rapidly developing field that has close connections to optimization, computer science, engineering, statistics, and even mathematical biology. Below we outline two main outcomes of the proposal.

 

The PI in collaboration with Alexander Barvinok and Seung Jin Lee worked on understanding the question of "What is the maximum number of faces that a centrally symmetric polytope of a given dimension and with a given number of vertices can have?" Polytopes are high-dimensional analogs of polygons (examples include high-dimensional cubes and pyramids), and a polytope is called centrally symmetric if it is symmetric about the origin. It is well-known that the boundary of a polytope we are looking for is a simplicial complex.

 

It was observed by Donoho and his collaborators that centrally symmetric polytopes with many faces have surprising implications in statistics, probability, information theory, and signal processing, and may have impacts in such subjects as medical imaging and digital communications. In the sequence of three papers, the PI and her collaborators provided an explicit construction of centrally symmetric polytopes of arbitrary dimension and with arbitrarily large number of vertices that (to-date) have a record number of edges; more generally, they provided a deterministic construction of centrally symmetric polytopes of arbitrary dimension and with arbitrarily large number of vertices that have a record number of low-dimensional faces.

 

In collaboration with Gil Kalai and Eran Nevo, the PI started developing the theory of bipartite rigidity of bipartite graphs. (A graph is bipartite if its vertices can be colored in two colors, so that every edge has one endpoint of each color.)  Classical rigidity is a very rich and important concept in its own right, with applications in such diverse fields as engineering and biology. The PI and her collaborators hope that the bipartite rigidity will eventually become as rich and fruitful. One unexpected outcome of this project is a joint work of the PI with Maria Chudnovsky, Gil Kalai, Eran Nevo, and Paul Seymour where we establish a bipartite analog of the celebrated Wagner’s theorem characterizing planar graphs.  Classical rigidity was successfully used (by Kalai and others) to find lower bounds on face numbers of triangulations of high-dimensional spheres, and more general spaces (such as manifolds and pseudomanifolds). One of our motivations in developing bipartite rigidity theory is its potential use in the study of face numbers of cubical complexes and more general cell complexes.

 

Broader impacts:  the PI is supervising graduate students, serves on the editorial board of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics,  and co-organizes various international conferences and workshops. She also co-organizers the Combinatorics seminar at the University of Washington.
